1.sofaString: China Undergoing an Industrial Revolution                 By MLNG                 BEHIND the of the Chiness crisis now worrying the whole world so much fies the explanation that the Chinese people are merely struggling as other people have done before to adapt themselves to the changing economic conditions of the present day brief review of the industrial conditions in Europe in the Middle Ages or 17th and 18th centuries will prove to es that China today is just undergoing an industrial revolution                 Industrial Revolution in Europe During the 17th and 18th centuries in Europe we find that the of manufacture were few and simple and such machinery as was utilized was crude and inexpensive Steam- power of course was unknown and water-power was but rarely employed Articles of all kinds were hand-made The term hand-craft denotes however form of industry not only based on hand-labor but devoid of capitalistic element The attention of the people living during that time was upon the homely operations of every day life the housewife drawing out her thread with distaff or spinning wheel the slow work of the weaver at his primitive loom They busied themselves with wheels cylinders bands and rollers patiently combining and recombining them t p to that time the people of western Europe for the most part continued to till their fields weave their cloth and saw and plane their boards by hand much as the ancient Egyptains had done Merchandise was still transported in slow lumber ing carts Suddenly however series of ingenious devices was invented which in few generations eclipsed the achieve ment of ages and revolutionized every branch of business Industrial Revolution in China Industrially speaking only two decades ago China was in the hand-craft stage Steam-power and water power were either unknown or rarely used Hut as result of her contact with the western world and as result of her emerging from several centuries of isolation machinery is now used in manufacture thus giving rise to the factory svstem -Manufacturing on small scale with the simple old tools and appliances has become increasingly unprofitable The primitive system is now being forced to compete with the cheaper goods of the Occident produced by machines driven by steam and electricity which enable one man to do the work of hundreds At the same time railways highways and steamships bring these articles to every town with minimum of cost for transportation Naturally the kers cannot meet the prices of machine-made commodities and arc gradually forced out of business and driven back to the already overcrowded land The whole social organi zation is disrupted That explains why within small area of the International Settlement there are about 50,000 risha coolies These coolies are forced to leave their homes to come to Shanghai to do such miserable work Employer Employees Tcday we hear very often of strikes in this or that factory or company So long as they arc not awakened to their rights and are willing to be the tools of other human beings workers can be treated in any way the please So long as they have no union the need not be afraid ot trouble So long as the standard of living is not high enough the rosy well pay wages of just few cents per day lUit the situation is quite different when laborers are conscious of their rights and are unwilling to be the of other human beings and the situation is ore serious if they have form of union and the standard of living becomes high One of the big problems for the Chinese sociologists to solve is that of the grinding poverty of the Chinese workers The annual per capita income in China has been estimated at only 0-- little more than the estimate of for India where the demands of climate are less rigorous it is calculated that in North China the minimum annual cost of food and clothing for family is 1M without considering rent heat and indispensable sundries but about percent of the families have less then this About ten years ago in the city of I'oochow it cost family of four persons ten dollars month to live but now it costs at least thirty dollars for the same kind of family Under these it is but that the Chinese workers must struggle for the nif nt in treat ment increase their wages and decrease their                 hours These constitute large part in the demands recently presented by strikers to their More Bitter Struggle To Come This is only the beginning of the struggle between the and' the employees believe Tlieir struggle is sure to assume more bitter and dangerous aspect in view of the size and rapid increase of the Chinese population the poverty of the workers and the ignorance of the Chinese laborers who can easily be stirred up by one or two words of professional strike agitator Furthermore only until recently the Chinese failed to realize what was occurring and did not take the necessary steps to adapt themselves to the inevitable Such struggle is destined to be more and more disastrous should the state stand aloof The Peking Govern ment which is now out of existence owing to its corruption did not care for the welfare of the people so they did not interfere with this struggle nor enact any law for ending it Adequate Labor Law Needed With the industrial revolution started period of struggle between and employees became inevitable The employers claim that they have rights as masters to dictate how much wage should be given to the laborers and how many hours thev should work 1! ut the employees reply that as we are now living in democratic world the have no right to treat them as they wish Further in view if the fact that the eight-hour system is now widely adopted in the world the Chinese laborers regardless of the difference in the condi tions at- once also demand that they should work only eight hours per day and that at the same time their wages be increased Their struggle is sure to be endless if our Govern ment does not pass law fixing the number of working per day and the amount of wages that should be paid In England there arc the Peel's Health and Morals Act of 180-'. the Factory Regulations Act of 1819, the Factory Act of 183.i, the Factory Act of 1844, Ten Hour Law of 1847, Factory and Workshop Act of 1878 and the Trade oard Act of 1909. In France there is the Child Labor Law of 1841 in Germany the Industrial Code of 1S91. What China needs today is an adequate labor law Certainly it is no easy task to draft Chinese labor law In drafting we must have in mind the interests of both the laborers and capitalists The sole aim of the labor law is to readjust the relationship between the and the employees We want to improve the status of the Chinese workers but at the same time we should improve the efficiency' of the Chinese laborers In other words the increase of the wages and decrease of working hours must be accompanied with the increase of the efficiency of the laborers Should the Chinese sociologists pay attention to this point and solve it in the long run we believe what is known as Chinese industrial unrest will pass The laborers of the Ford Motor Car Co in America work only eight hours per day but the efficiency of the laborers is so that it does not matter if the hours are father decreased So it is my conviction that the time has come for the capitalists not to think too much of enriching themselves at the expense of the laborers and the time has also come for the laborers not to think that to strike is the best policy They must cooperate with each other Child Labor Be Prohibited The employment of children in industry is phase of the general problem of child welfare involving far-reaching physical moral mental and economic effect Employment of children in modern industry prevents moral physical and mental development The period of schooling is cut short by the necessity of entering industry and the confinement and strain of industrial life are likely to injure the child perma nently The undeveloped muscular and nervous systems arc unable to resist the wear and tear of toil and fatigue soon sets in It has been found that children are much more liable to industrial accidents and more susceptible to occupational diseases than adults Experience has also shown that child labor and delinquency are intimately related and that the child who enters industry at an early age is likely to feel his economic importance and to become less amenable to parental control It is really terrible to visit some of the iron shops in China These shops usually employ small boys below 15 years of age These boys are forced to work early in the morning until late in the evening They have to take up heavy hammers to strike on piece of heated iron all dav long Such hard work is not even suitable for men certainly not for boys It is true that child labor occurs in every country But the situation is more terrible in China in view the fact that large masses of the Chinese population are unemployed and the parents arc anxious to send their children to in the factories or shops regardless what kind of work they must do It is up to the State to protect the interests of these children
